summary: This document appears to be notes or a summary of a November 30, 2021 call with Gail Goodman, discussing memory research, particularly the reliability of memories of traumatic events like sexual abuse, and critiquing the work of Elizabeth Loftus. It focuses on the scientific debate about false memories versus the strength of memories for self-relevant, traumatic events, especially from adolescence.

persons.name: Gail Goodman
persons.context: Participant in a call discussing memory research, particularly the reliability of memories of traumatic events like sexual abuse, and critiquing the work of Elizabeth Loftus.

persons.name: Elizabeth Loftus
persons.context: Her research on false memory creation is discussed and critiqued in the context of the reliability of memories for traumatic events like sexual abuse.

connections.description: Goodman critiques Loftus's research methodologies and conclusions regarding the prevalence and creation of false memories, particularly for traumatic events like sexual abuse.

events.title: Call with Gail Goodman
events.description: A call discussing memory research, focusing on the reliability of memories for traumatic events like sexual abuse and critiquing Elizabeth Loftus's false memory studies.

events.title: Denver Sexual Abuse Study
events.description: Gail Goodman conducted a federally funded study following 200 victims (ages 4-17) in sexual abuse cases through the courts in Denver.

keyFacts: The document records a 2021 expert discussion on memory, specifically addressing the reliability of memories of sexual abuse from adolescence.
Gail Goodman argues that memories for self-relevant, traumatic events (like sexual abuse) are often strong and accurate, contrary to some false memory research.
Goodman cites her own studies, including one following 200 child sexual abuse victims in Denver courts in the 1980s, to support the reliability of such memories.
The discussion critiques Elizabeth Loftus's false memory research as being based on contrived, low-stakes studies that may not generalize to real traumatic events.
The document suggests memory is particularly robust for events occurring in adolescence (the 'adolescent bump'), which is relevant to many allegations in the Epstein case.
